0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, in patients who fail to respond adequately to other antiemetic agents: 1 to 2 mg ORALLY twice daily; first dose should be given 1 to 3 hours before chemotherapy; start with 1 mg to minimize side effects and increase dose as necessary; may also be helpful to administer 1 or 2 mg the night prior to chemotherapy; may be administered 2 or 3 times daily during the entire course of each cycle of chemotherapy; if required, continue up to 48 hours after the last dose of chemotherapy; MAX 6 mg a day in 3 divided doses

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and efficacy not established in children younger than 18 years of age

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, in patients who fail to respond adequately to other antiemetic agents

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to marijuana or other cannabinoids

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• central nervous system effects can occur; may be persistent (up to 72 hours) and unpredictable
  • concomitant use of central nervous system depressants or other psychoactive drugs; additive or synergistic effects may occur
  • elderly patients; increased risk of postural hypotension
  • heart disease; increased risk of postural hypotension
  • hepatic dysfunction
  • hypertension; increased risk of postural hypotension
  • orthostatic hypotension may occur
  • potential for abuse or dependence; prescriptions should be limited to the smallest amount needed for a single course of chemotherapy
  • psychiatric disorders, current or history; use may unmask symptoms of disorders such as manic depression, depression, and schizophrenia
  • substance abuse, history
  • tachycardia may occur

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Hypotension (8%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Xerostomia (22% to 36%)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia (8%), Ataxia (13% to 14%), Dyssomnia (11%), Headache (6% to 7%), Poor concentration (12%), Somnolence (52% to 66%), Vertigo (52% to 59%)
  • Ophthalmic:Visual disturbance (13%)
  • Psychiatric:Dysphoric mood (9%)
  • Other:Euphoria (11% to 38%)
Serious
Psychiatric:Psychotic disorder

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Oral: time to peak concentration, 2 h
  • Bioavailability: 95.6% to 100%
  • Effect of food: none

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Fecal: 60% to 65% as metabolites or unchanged
  • Renal: 20% to 24% as metabolites or unchanged

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: signs of excessive use, abuse, and misuse

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Patient should avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause poor concentration or somnolence.
  • Instruct patient to rise slowly from a sitting/supine position, as drug may cause orthostatic hypotension. Patients who are elderly or those having heart disease or hypertension may be at higher risk for this effect.
  • This drug may cause xerostomia, asthenia, ataxia, dyssomnia, headache, vertigo, visual disturbance, dysphoric mood, or euphoria.
  • Drug may cause or unmask symptoms of psychotic disorder. Instruct patient to report worsening depression, suicidal ideation, or unusual changes in behavior.
  • Instruct patient to not drink alcohol or use CNS depressants or other psychoactive drugs while taking this drug, as this may cause additive or synergistic effects.
